unclassified forms |Rubric=Definition |Contributors= |Order=1}} Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) (formerly functional colopathy) is a clinical diagnosis defined by the presence of abdominal pain associated with transit disorders in the absence of any organic digestive disease. By definition, all complementary tests are normal. It is a benign but chronic pathology with a significant deterioration in quality of life. There are 4 subtypes of IBS, depending on the predominant transit. - IBS with predominant diarrhoea (IBS-D), - IBS with predominant constipation (IBS-C) - IBS with alternating diarrhoea and constipation (IBS-A) - IBS indeterminate (IBS-I), for patients who do not fall into any of the 3 subgroups

question.title: What are the four subtypes of Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)?

option_a.title: IBS with predominant diarrhoea (IBS-D), IBS with predominant constipation (IBS-C), IBS with alternating diarrhoea and constipation (IBS-M), and IBS with abdominal pain only (IBS-P)

option_b.title: IBS with predominant diarrhoea (IBS-D), IBS with predominant constipation (IBS-C), IBS with alternating diarrhoea and constipation (IBS-M), and IBS with a combination of symptoms (IBS-CM)

option_c.title: IBS with predominant diarrhoea (IBS-D), IBS with predominant constipation (IBS-C), IBS with alternating diarrhoea and constipation (IBS-M), and IBS with no clear symptoms (IBS-NS)

option_d.title: IBS with predominant diarrhoea (IBS-D), IBS with predominant constipation (IBS-C), IBS with alternating diarrhoea and constipation (IBS-M), and IBS indeterminate (IBS-I)

correct_option.title: IBS with predominant diarrhoea (IBS-D), IBS with predominant constipation (IBS-C), IBS with alternating diarrhoea and constipation (IBS-M), and IBS indeterminate (IBS-I)
